training_organizations.name: Tennessee DCS Office of Training & Professional Development
training_organizations.description: Tennessee’s Department of Children’s Services, in partnership with the University of Tennessee (SWORPS), operates a comprehensive training program for child welfare staff. New DCS case managers attend Pre-Service training (which includes classroom instruction and hands-on field practice) and must demonstrate core competencies. Ongoing in-service training and a formal mentoring program are provided to continually build skills. This centralized training supports Tennessee’s mix of state and private service delivery by ensuring DCS staff are well-prepared to manage cases and oversee providers.

training_organizations.name: Youth Villages
training_organizations.description: A nonprofit organization headquartered in Tennessee that provides a wide array of children’s services. Under DCS contracts, Youth Villages delivers foster care and transitional living programs. It specializes in therapeutic foster care – recruiting and training foster parents to care for teens or children with behavioral issues – and provides intensive in-home services (Intercept program) to help reunify families. Youth Villages is a key partner in Tennessee’s child welfare system, often handling some of the most challenging cases with its private resources:contentReference[oaicite:39]{index=39}.

training_organizations.name: Omni Visions
training_organizations.description: A private agency in Tennessee that contracts with DCS to provide foster care and other services. Omni Visions recruits therapeutic foster homes and serves children with special needs (such as developmental disabilities or medical complexities). They also provide services like home studies and case management for some DCS-referred cases. By utilizing agencies like Omni, Tennessee ensures children who require specialized foster placements can receive care from trained private foster families:contentReference[oaicite:40]{index=40}.

training_organizations.name: Camelot Care Centers
training_organizations.description: A private child welfare agency active in Tennessee, contracting with DCS for foster care and behavioral health services. Camelot oversees foster homes for children and youth with emotional or behavioral issues, provides counseling and foster parent training, and sometimes manages adoption services. It operates under performance-based contracts – DCS assigns certain cases to Camelot case managers, and Camelot is accountable for safety, stability, and permanency outcomes for those children:contentReference[oaicite:41]{index=41}.

training_organizations.name: Bethany Christian Services (Tennessee)
training_organizations.description: A national faith-based organization with local operations in Tennessee, Bethany provides foster care and adoption services via contracts and partnerships. In Tennessee, Bethany recruits foster families (including for refugee minors and special needs children) and works with DCS to place children in those homes. They also facilitate adoptions for children who cannot return to their birth families. Bethany’s involvement supplements DCS efforts, particularly in finding family-based care for children who might otherwise remain in shelters or group settings:contentReference[oaicite:42]{index=42}.

perpetrator_relationships.relationship: Victim Was Child of Boyfriend or Girlfriend

policies.TribalFoster: No, Tribes within state do not provide foster care
policies.DefAge_Specify: Under age 18 with variability under 18 and over 18
policies.FatalitiesReview: Yes, reviews are required for all or some cases
policies.Def_Subtype_Abuse: Physical abuse includes exposure to drugs or drug lab, violent behavior by a parent in the presence of a child (e.g. domestic violence); Sexual abuse includes trafficking and child prostitution; Factitious disorder by proxy can be considered physical abuse or psychological abuse; Failure to protect can be considered physical abuse or sexual abuse
policies.Def_Subtype_Neglect: Neglect includes inadequate clothing, nutritional neglect, medical neglect, abandonment, environmental neglect, and inability to meet parent responsibilities (unfit parent); Parental drug or alcohol misuse is an example of lack of supervision, which is neglect; Factitious disorder by proxy could be considered medical neglect
policies.DefPerp_OtherSpecify: A person who has allegedly used the child for the purpose of commercial sexual exploitation of a minor or trafficking a minor for a commercial sex act, including, but not limited to, a trafficker
policies.NearFatalitiesReview: Yes, reviews are required for all or some cases
policies.Screener_OtherSpecify: Each region within the state has specialized staff to assist in assignments and secondary screening of reports
policies.InvestReq_OtherSpecify: Photograph the child, injuries, and/or environment, any objects/items used to cause the injury or condition; Obtain medical records as appropriate
policies.ScreenInfo_OtherSpecify: Whether parties meet criteria for assignment to the Special Investigations Unit; Whether report meets the criteria for Resource Linkage services
policies.DefAge_VaryByTypeSpecify: A child is a person under 18 or a person under 19 who remains under the jurisdiction of a juvenile court
policies.InvestQual_TrainingSpecify: Specialized on-boarding and in-service trainings for investigators
policies.InvestQual_ExperienceSpecify: Department of Children's Services (DCS) Case Manager 1 staff do not require experience; DCS Case Manager 2 staff must have experience equivalent to one year of full-time professional work providing child welfare services; DCS Case Manager 3 staff must have two years of professional experience providing child welfare services; DCS Case Manager 4 staff with a master's degree in social work or a related behavioral science field must have experience equivalent to three years of full-time professional child welfare case work; DCS Case Manager 4 staff with a bachelor's degree in any field must have experience equivalent to five years of full-time professional child welfare case work
policies.InvestReq_OtherCases_Specify: Photograph of the child, injuries, and/or environment is required for all severe abuse allegations, sexual abuse, child death/near death, physical abuse, environmental neglect, nutritional neglect, and drug exposed children; Obtain medical records as appropriate is required for all severe abuse allegations, sexual abuse, child death/near death, drug exposed children, and medical neglect
policies.ScreenerQual_TrainingSpecify: Specialized onboarding and in-service trainings for screeners
policies.AntiDiscrim_Staff_VarySpecify: (1) Race, national origin, and color are specified for staff from child welfare agency and contracted child welfare provider organizations; (2) Disability  is specified for staff from child welfare agency
policies.FatalitiesDefine_OtherSpecify: Any unexplained death of a child when the cause of death is unknown or pending an autopsy report
policies.CaseManagerQual_ExperienceSpec: Department of Children's Services (DCS) Case Manager 1 staff do not require experience; DCS Case Manager 2 staff must have experience equivalent to one year of full-time professional work providing child welfare services; DCS Case Manager 3 staff must have two years of professional experience providing child welfare services; DCS Case Manager 4 staff with a master's degree in social work or a related behavioral science field must have experience equivalent to three years of full-time professional child welfare case work; DCS Case Manager 4 staff with a bachelor's degree in any field must have experience equivalent to five years of full-time professional child welfare case work
policies.InvestReq_MedEvalCases_Specify: Severe abuse, sexual abuse, child death-near death, drug-exposed infant/child
policies.ScreenerQual_ExperienceSpecify: Department of Children's Services (DCS) Case Manager 1 staff do not require experience; DCS Case Manager 2 staff must have experience equivalent to one year of full-time professional work providing child welfare services; DCS Case Manager 3 staff must have two years of professional experience providing child welfare services; DCS Case Manager 4 staff with a master's degree in social work or a related behavioral science field must have experience equivalent to three years of full-time professional child welfare case work; DCS Case Manager 4 staff with a bachelor's degree in any field must have experience equivalent to five years of full-time professional child welfare case work
policies.AltResp_EligibilityMaltreatment: Only certain types of maltreatment are eligible
policies.CaseManagerQual_TrainingSpecify: Specialized on-boarding trainings for foster care
